title: How to Plant Cover Crops

steps.headline: Test your soil’s nutrient levels with a kit or a soil sample.
steps.description: You can purchase a DIY soil-testing kit from a nursery, which gives you a general idea of your soil’s levels. For a more accurate assessment, you can pay to send a soil sample to a professional lab. After you receive the results, pick your cover crop based on what your soil needs to balance its deficiencies. Some common adjustments include providing nitrogen, adding organic matter, improving soil structure, reducing soil erosion, and providing weed control. Common areas for soil deficiency include nitrogen, phosphorous, or aeration.

steps.headline: Plant small grains or grasses to enrich and break up compacted soil.
steps.description: Grass crops like oats, barley, annual ryegrass, and winter rye all produce high quantities of organic matter for the soil. Their root systems also help them to break up thick clay soil and stay extremely hardy against the cold. The easiest grasses to grow include rye (annual or cereal) and buckwheat.

steps.headline: Choose a legume crop to improve your soil’s nitrogen production.
steps.description: Pick from a wide selection of legumes, such as clovers (crimson, red, Dutch white, berseem, sweet, and more), hairy vetch, fava beans, bell beans, and Austrian winter peas. Legumes are perfect for replacing the nitrogen that previous crops may have taken from the soil. In fact, legumes can produce up to 300 pounds (140 kg) of nitrogen per acre of soil. If the seed company hasn’t pre-inoculated them, you’ll need to inoculate your legume seeds 24 hours prior to planting. This process involves coating all of the seeds with rhizobacteria to increase nitrogen production.

steps.headline: Use brassicas, buckwheat, or phacelia for fixing a variety of soil issues.
steps.description: These crops form a kind of “miscellaneous” third group. Brassicas, such as oilseed radish and mustard, are known for having 4 feet (1.2 m) roots that chisel and loosen compacted soil. Buckwheat is perfect for accumulating phosphorus in the soil, and phacelia is great for attracting bees in early spring for pollination.

steps.headline: Combine 2 crops to produce and store nitrogen in the soil.
steps.description: For the best results, try a crop cover combination of both grass and legume seeds. You can either make your own pairing, checking first that the 2 seeds are compatible, or purchase a pre-formulated blend. Most seed companies offer these special blends so you don’t have to worry about proportions. Some good combinations include vetch with oats, Austrian peas with winter wheat, and garden peas with rye. One of the most effective legume-grass blends is the field pea and oat combination. You get the best of both worlds—nitrogen and organic matter—and the 2 plants even have complementary growth habits.

steps.headline: Plan to plant the seeds about 4 weeks before the first frost.
steps.description: This gives the seeds plenty of time to be established before the cold weather hits. Mark the date on your calendar and have your seeds and tools ready. However, some seeds need more time in warm weather to properly germinate, so check the instructions on the seed package. The main exception is cereal rye, which can be planted any time up until the first frost.

steps.headline: Inoculate your legumes within 24 hours prior to planting.
steps.description: Many companies pre-inoculate their seeds, but if yours haven’t gone through this process, you’ll need to do it yourself. Purchase a specific inoculant based on the packaging instructions, then wet the seeds with non-chlorinated water. Mix them with the inoculant in a wheelbarrow or plastic pail until they’re fully coated. You can either plant the seeds right away or let them dry in the shade for 24 hours. Always complete the inoculation process in the shade, since sunlight can damage the seeds. If you’re not sure whether your seeds have been inoculated, check the packaging. Seed companies will usually print this information clearly.

steps.headline: Loosen the soil up with a garden rake or tiller.
steps.description: Raking ensures that you’ll have good seed-to-soil contact, which encourages healthy growth. If your soil is well-aerated and broken up already, you only need to loosen it with a garden rake. If your soil is compacted, you’ll need to till it at least 3 to 4 in (7.6 to 10.2 cm) down. If your soil is full of leftover vegetation, use a hard metal rake to remove it, then smooth the soil out evenly.

steps.headline: Spread the seeds evenly and liberally.
steps.description: You can either spread the seed by hand or use a seed spreader, just like you would to spread grass seed. The exact ratio of seed to soil varies between crop types, so follow the instructions on the seed package. Application rates can range from 1 to 4 pounds (0.45 to 1.81 kg) per 1,000 square feet (93 m).

steps.headline: Rake the seeds into the soil to provide some protection.
steps.description: Covering up the seeds in the soil generates good soil-to-seed contact, helps keep them safe from birds, and protects against cold temperatures. Use a garden rake to turn the soil over and give the seeds some soil coverage. Small seeds like rye need to stay close to the surface, so just give them a light rake. Larger seeds, such as fava beans, need deeper coverage, so rake these more vigorously.

steps.headline: Water the seeds until the first frost.
steps.description: You can use a sprinkler, set up an irrigation system, or just let the rain do the work for you. Once the temperature hits freezing, stop watering and let the plant enter dormancy.

steps.headline: Let the plants naturally come out of dormancy and continue growing.
steps.description: Once the frost is over, the seeds will resume growth in the spring. Since cover crops are low-maintenance, you can virtually leave them alone until you’re ready to plant your new spring crop.

steps.headline: Kill the cover crop in the spring when it grows flowers or seedpods.
steps.description: At this point, the cover crop has done its job! Before the plants set seed and the top growth gets out of control, you’ll need to cut them off at the base. As the temperatures rise after winter and spring gets underway, monitor the plants daily. This should usually occur 3-4 weeks before you’re ready to plant your new vegetables or flowers. You get the maximum amount of nutrients out of the cover crop by letting the plant mature as much as possible, but cutting it off before it can develop seeds.

steps.headline: Cut the plants to the ground with a mower, weed-eater, or loppers.
steps.description: The goal is to remove the plants at their base so they die quickly and start decomposing to add more nutrients to the soil. Choose the tools you use based on the size of your garden. Larger spaces may need a rototiller or mower, while smaller gardens may only need a weed-eater or some loppers. Some crops need to be mowed at a specific time. For example, winter annual rye will only die from mowing if you cut it after it creates a seed head, but before it releases its seeds. On the other hand, Austrian peas will die easily and can be mowed at any time. As a general rule, this method will work on all annuals.

steps.headline: Let the clippings decompose on the surface for a week before tilling.
steps.description: This will give the plants enough time to act as a mulch, releasing nutrients into the soil and enriching it for the next crop. After waiting a week, till the clippings into the soil by flipping and mixing them with a rototiller, spade, or garden fork (small crops). Till in long, straight rows in order to cover the entire surface of the soil.

steps.headline: Wait another 2-3 weeks before planting any vegetables or flowers.
steps.description: After the soil has had some time to recover, it’s revitalized and ready for a new crop. Plant your vegetables and fruit as you normally would, and expect a great yield from your refreshed, nutrient-rich soil!
